author: bob1029
comment_text: There is a "best practices" way to do canvas drawing which involves requestAnimationFrame inside a draw loop function, but there is no way to put UI events and drawing on different logical threads. The best you can do is make sure your draw function does not do non-drawing things.
story_title: Making the whole web better, one canvas at a time

comment_text.value: There is a "best practices" way to do canvas drawing which involves requestAnimationFrame inside a draw loop function, but there is no way to put UI events and drawing on different logical threads. The best you can do is make sure your draw function does not do non-drawing things.

story_title.value: Making the whole web better, one canvas at a time

author: SkyMarshal
comment_text:
A little late here but just want to add, the original MIT article is paywalled if you’ve read more than your 2 free monthly stories there. The Relevant magazine story is not.

Also it is of interest that a Christian culture magazine is reporting on this, as that’s the kind of thing that needs to happen en masse to fix this problem. It needs to become a main topic of discussion in the communities being targeted by troll farms, and not just in tech circles.

That this article shows that is happening is newsworthy in and of itself.
story_title: Almost All of Facebook’s Top Christian Pages in 2019 Run by Foreign Troll Farms

comment_text.value:

author: elzbardico
comment_text:
Some people think developers should always work for free to enrich the executive and investing classes. 
I think that making enterprise pay for stuff that matters for enterprises while still providing open source for society should be seen as a positive, sustainable model.
story_title: Rancher Desktop, a Docker Desktop Replacement

author: krastanov
comment_text: Yes, you are right. However, this "design choice" makes things less efficient and more cumbersome to compute, not the other way around. There are easy ways to get random numbers from continuous dynamics that do not involve something as painful as quantum fields. There are also some consistency arguments (contradictions arising in classical theories that do not exist in quantum theories, so maybe it was not even a "choice", but the only way to make a self-consistent simulation). And there is the whole interpreation-of-quantum-mechanics issue: it is a separate can of worms to even claim that measurements of quantum observables produce random outcomes (but that question is too philosophical for me).
story_title: Quantum Annealing opens a new door to Simulation Hypothesis

comment_text.value: Yes, you are right. However, this "design choice" makes things less efficient and more cumbersome to compute, not the other way around. There are easy ways to get random numbers from continuous dynamics that do not involve something as painful as quantum fields. There are also some consistency arguments (contradictions arising in classical theories that do not exist in quantum theories, so maybe it was not even a "choice", but the only way to make a self-consistent simulation). And there is the whole interpreation-of-quantum-mechanics issue: it is a separate can of worms to even claim that measurements of quantum observables produce random outcomes (but that question is too philosophical for me).

story_title.value: Quantum Annealing opens a new door to Simulation Hypothesis

author: red_trumpet
comment_text:
> even one where the onerous regulations go away and a market price on carbon is available

What do you mean by a "market price of carbon"? From context I would guess that the "market price" would be higher than the current price, but the history has told us otherwise - that is why we have regulations on carbon emissions.
story_title: Major nuclear fusion milestone reached as ‘ignition’ triggered in a lab

author: 908B64B197
comment_text:
> I must admit I'd forgotten about Magic Leap, amazed to see they're still going and raising even more money.

It's basically the only alternative for an investor who wants to get into AR, other than buying MSFT of AAPL stocks. That's why, despite shipping a V1 almost as good as the HoloLens V1 they are getting funded again.

Problem is, by the time Magic Leap gets it's V2 out there's a good chance we'll be seeing HoloLens V3 in the field.

comment_text.value:
> I must admit I'd forgotten about Magic Leap, amazed to see they're still going and raising even more money.

It's basically the only alternative for an investor who wants to get into AR, other than buying MSFT of AAPL stocks. That's why, despite shipping a V1 almost as good as the HoloLens V1 they are getting funded again.

Problem is, by the time Magic Leap gets it's V2 out there's a good chance we'll be seeing HoloLens V3 in the field.

author: aledalgrande
comment_text:
> Doesn't scaling take time, though? Doesn't downloading a new docker container definition and starting it take at least as long as initializing a new lambda function?

Yes, especially because they still don't support caching the image locally for Fargate. If you start a new instance with autoscaling, or restart one, you have to download the full image again. Depending on its size, start times can be minutes...

comment_text.value:
> Doesn't scaling take time, though? Doesn't downloading a new docker container definition and starting it take at least as long as initializing a new lambda function?

Yes, especially because they still don't support caching the image locally for Fargate. If you start a new instance with autoscaling, or restart one, you have to download the full image again. Depending on its size, start times can be minutes...

author: raywu
comment_text:
Your question is great and barring other incentives (comments in response to this), I’m also interested in how commercial viability impedes adoption.

In your opinion, what could be done to make the energy generated by fusion competitive? Can we add storage to the mix and therefore compete on a longer time horizon? I know storage itself is expensive.

Is it to say that fusion won’t get adoption from market forces alone, until the cost of construction lowers?
story_title: Major nuclear fusion milestone reached as ‘ignition’ triggered in a lab

author: brightball
comment_text:
Their carbon emissions are still dramatically lower than those of coal and oil. There are bigger fish to fry than NG.

NG is likely going to be a critical transitional fuel for the planet to depend on while we get to more abundant renewable options, grid batteries and nuclear/fusion/thorium.
story_title: Major nuclear fusion milestone reached as ‘ignition’ triggered in a lab
